items.title: 'Money grab': 'Ten-pound Pom' vows to boycott UK over passport changes
items.description: People who came to Australia as children from the UK as part of an organised migration scheme say they are part of a cohort being unfairly targeted by the UK's new regulations for dual citizens.

items.title: Debt is America's Achilles heel in a fracturing world order
items.description: For decades, global investors have bought US government debt as a safe haven when things turn pear-shaped. But investor attitudes are changing, and America's financial domination is at stake.

items.title: Australia earns global praise for economic 'soft landing'
items.description: A new report from the OECD says Australia's economy is returning to normal but remains vulnerable and lacks dynamism.

items.title: Nationals walkout leaves Coalition on life support, again
items.description: The departure of every single member of the Nationals from the frontbench is bizarrely both a failure of the Coalition agreement and a result of it functioning as intended.

items.title: Fetal heart monitors still available online despite being banned
items.description: Home fetal doppler devices were banned from sale in Australia last year but they are still readily available for purchase online, prompting experts to issue warnings.

items.title: Bondi lifeguard who ran towards terror attack remembers 'fear in victims' eyes'
items.description: Much of Jackson "Jacko" Doolan's memory from December 14 is a blur, but there is one moment that remains crystal clear.

items.title: Republicans push to hold Clintons in contempt of Congress over Epstein probe
items.description: The Clintons are refusing to testify before a committee in the US House of Representatives, accusing Republicans of leading a weaponised process against them.

items.title: Trump's Board of Peace gains members ahead of Davos signing

featured_image.name: US President Donald Trump departs White House for World Economic Forum in Davos

items.description:
US President Donald Trump's newly created "Board of Peace" is gaining members while exposing rifts among Western nations, as the initiative designed to oversee Gaza's reconstruction expands into a broader conflict-resolution body that some fear could challenge the United Nations.

On Wednesday, divisions sharpened as Israel, Egypt, Bahrain, Azerbaijan, and Kosovo announced they would join the board, while Norway and Sweden followed France in declining the invitation. A White House official said about 30 countries are expected to sign on, with 50 having received invitations.[1][2]

Trump is scheduled to hold a formal signing ceremony Thursday at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where the charter will be officially established.[3][4]

items.title: 'Constant worry': Ukraine endures bitterest winter as Russia targets energy sites
items.description: The war-ravaged country has been plunged into an energy crisis as temperatures plummet below freezing, leaving millions unable to heat their homes.

items.title: Interstellar object 3I/ATLAS to reach optimal viewing alignment

featured_image.name: Brand new image of interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS shows it's ...

items.description:
Harvard astrophysicist Avi Loeb has published an essay cataloguing 18 unusual characteristics of interstellar object 3I/ATLAS, raising questions about whether the cosmic visitor could be artificial rather than a natural comet. The provocative analysis, titled "What if 3I/ATLAS Is AI/ATLAS?" arrives as the object approaches a rare near-opposition alignment on January 22, 2026, offering astronomers an unprecedented observational window.[1][2]

Loeb, the former chair of Harvard's astronomy department, states that 3I/ATLAS is "most likely natural" but argues the anomalies warrant investigation. He ranks the object at 4 on his self-devised 10-point "Loeb Scale" for interstellar significance.[3][1]

items.title: Mountain regions warming faster than lowlands, threatening water for billions

featured_image.name: Himalayan glacier melting threatens water security for ...

items.description:
The past 11 years have been the warmest in modern history, the World Meteorological Organization confirmed last week, as scientists warn that global warming is intensifying heatwaves, floods, and storms while threatening water supplies for more than a billion people.

The WMO reported that 2025 ranked among the three warmest years on record, with global average surface temperatures reaching 1.44°C above pre-industrial levels. Six of eight international climate datasets ranked 2025 as the third-warmest year, while two ranked it second-warmest in the 176-year temperature record. The findings came despite the cooling influence of La Niña conditions at the start and end of the year.[1][2][3]

"The year 2025 started and ended with a cooling La Niña and yet it was still one of the warmest years on record globally because of the accumulation of heat-trapping greenhouse gases in our atmosphere," said WMO Secretary-General Celeste Saulo.[2][1]

items.title: Pew report finds Catholicism declining sharply across Latin America

featured_image.name: Pope Francis' popularity plummets in the U.S. and 6 Latin ...

items.description:
A new report from the Pew Research Center released Wednesday reveals that Catholicism continues to decline across Latin America, with the Catholic share of the population falling by at least 9 percentage points in each of six major countries surveyed over the past decade. The findings mirror broader trends of Christian disaffiliation documented by Pew across Europe, where millions have left the faith since childhood.

The report, titled "Catholicism Has Declined in Latin America Over the Past Decade," is based on surveys of more than 6,200 adults conducted in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, and Peru between January and April 2024. These six nations collectively represent about 75% of Latin America's population.[1][2]

"Our analysis found that the Catholic share of the population in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru has significantly declined since 2013-14, while a growing share of adults in the region are religiously unaffiliated," said Kirsten Lesage, a Pew research associate and the report's lead author.[3][4]

items.title: Indonesian cave hand stencil becomes oldest dated rock art

featured_image.name: Oldest known rock art is a 68,000-year-old hand stencil with claws

items.description: A faded hand stencil found in a cave on Indonesia's Muna Island has been dated to at least 67,800 years ago, making it the oldest reliably dated rock art ever discovered. The finding, published Wednesday in the journal Nature, surpasses the previous record holder — hand stencils attributed to Neanderthals in Spain — by more than a millennium and offers new insights into early human migration toward Australia.[1][2][3]

items.title: Trump rules out force for Greenland, demands negotiations

featured_image.name: Trump says no nation can secure Greenland but the US in Davos speech

items.description:
President Donald Trump delivered a defiant 72-minute speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland on Wednesday, ruling out military force to acquire Greenland while demanding "immediate negotiations" with Denmark over the Arctic territory and criticizing European allies as heading in the "wrong direction."

The address, widely anticipated as a pivotal moment in escalating transatlantic tensions, saw Trump claim Greenland as American territory while simultaneously attempting to reassure nervous European partners. "We probably won't get anything unless I decide to use excessive strength and force, where we would be, frankly, unstoppable. But I won't do that," Trump told the audience of billionaires, government officials, and diplomats.[1][2]

items.title: Unsealed emails show Microsoft pushed OpenAI toward rapid monetization

featured_image.name: OpenAI's Altman posts pic with Microsoft's Nadella, touts ...

items.description:
Newly unsealed internal communications from Elon Musk's lawsuit against OpenAI and Microsoft show how Microsoft executives actively shaped the AI startup's rapid pivot from a cautious nonprofit into one of the most valuable companies in technology. The documents, made public through legal discovery, offer a rare glimpse into the corporate maneuvering that transformed OpenAI from an obscure research lab into a company now valued at $500 billion.

GeekWire journalist Todd Bishop examined the cache of emails, memos, and text messages, revealing that Microsoft's leadership, including CEO Satya Nadella, pushed aggressively for monetization at critical junctures in OpenAI's development.[1][2]

items.title: EU leaders to hold emergency summit over Greenland tensions

featured_image.name: EU Commission President von der Leyen attends WEF in Davos

items.description:
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen declared Wednesday that the European Union stands "at a crossroads" as tensions with the United States over Greenland escalate, warning that President Donald Trump's tariff threats risk triggering a "dangerous downward spiral" between allies.

"Europe prefers dialogue and solutions – but we are fully prepared to act, if necessary, with unity, urgency and determination," von der Leyen told the European Parliament in Strasbourg, signaling a more forceful approach to Trump's persistent pressure campaign to acquire the Arctic territory from Denmark.[1][2][3]

items.title: Canadian PM Carney says US-led global order is over

featured_image.name: Canada 'Stands Firmly' With Greenland, Denmark: PM Carney

items.description:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney declared the end of the American-led rules-based international order on Tuesday, urging "middle powers" like Canada to band together against coercion from larger nations in an address at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland that delivered a direct rebuke to U.S. President Donald Trump's territorial ambitions.

Speaking in both French and English to the assembled global elite, Carney described a "rupture" in global affairs where "the powerful act as they wish, while the vulnerable endure what they must." The speech came just hours after Trump posted AI-generated images on Truth Social depicting American flags overlaid on Canada, Greenland, Cuba, and Venezuela.[1][2][3]

items.title: Trump demands Greenland talks at Davos, rules out force

featured_image.name: Trump delivers speech at World Economic Forum

items.description:
President Donald Trump delivered a combative speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday, using the global gathering to press his case for acquiring Greenland while criticizing European allies and calling Denmark "ungrateful" for refusing to cede the territory.

"No nation or coalition of nations is in any position to be able to secure Greenland other than the United States," Trump told the assembled business leaders and diplomats. "We're a great power, much greater than people even understand."[1][2][3]

The speech came amid unprecedented tensions between the United States and its European allies, with Trump threatening tariffs on eight NATO countries unless they support his bid to purchase the semi-autonomous Danish territory.

items.title: Breaking: Trump drops Greenland tariffs threat as he heralds 'future deal' with NATO
items.description: Donald Trump says he has agreed to a "framework of a future deal" on Greenland after talks with NATO's secretary-general, and he will no longer impose tariffs on European nations that had opposed a US takeover.

items.title: City real estate prices on record rebound as million-dollar club grows
items.description: The Melbourne real estate market is leading a "decisive recovery", according to property portal Domain, as the city hits a four-year high for its median house price after strong growth across the country last year.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
